2:
"Oh, if only my anguish were weighed;\q if only all my calamity were laid in the balance!
\q
3:
For now it would be heavier than the sand of the seas.\q That is why my words were reckless.


\q
5:
Does the wild donkey bray in despair when he has grass?\q Or does the ox low in hunger when it has fodder?
\q
6:
Can that which has no taste be eaten without salt?\q Or is there any taste in the white of an egg?


\q
7:
I refuse to touch them;\q they are like disgusting food to me.
\q
8:
Oh, that I might have my request;\q oh, that God would grant me the thing I long for:
\q
9:
that it would please God to crush me once,\q that he would let loose his hand and cut me off from this life!


\q
10:
May this still be my consolationâ€”\q even if I exult in pain that does not lessen:
\q that I have not denied the words of the Holy One.
\q
11:
What is my strength, that I should try to wait?\q What is my end, that I should prolong my life?


\q
12:
Is my strength the strength of stones?\q Or is my flesh made of bronze?
\q
13:
Is it not true that I have no help in myself,\q and that wisdom has been driven out of me?


\q
14:
To the person who is about to faint, faithfulness should be shown by his friend;\q even to him who forsakes the fear of the Almighty.
\q
15:
But my brothers have been as faithful to me as a desert streambed,\q as channels of water that pass away to nothing,
\q
16:
which are darkened because of ice over them,\q and because of the snow that hides itself in them.
\q
17:
When they thaw out, they vanish;\q when it is hot, they melt out of their place.


\q
18:
The caravans that travel by their way turn aside for water;\q they wander into barren land and then perish.
\q
19:
Caravans from Tema looked there,\q while companies of Sheba hoped in them.
\q
20:
They were disappointed because they had been confident of finding water.\q They went there, but they were deceived.


\q
21:
For now you friends are nothing to me;\q you see my dreadful situation and are afraid.
\q
22:
Did I say to you, 'Give something to me?'\q Or, 'Offer me a gift from your wealth?'
\q
23:
Or, 'Save me from my adversary's hand?'\q Or, 'Ransom me from the hand of my oppressors?'


\q
24:
Teach me, and I will hold my peace;\q make me understand where I have been wrong.
\q
25:
How painful are truthful words!\q But your arguments, how do they actually rebuke me?


\q
26:
Do you plan to ignore my words,
\q treating the words of a desperate man like the wind?
\q
27:
Indeed, you cast lots for a fatherless child,\q and haggle over your friend like merchandise.


\q
28:
Now, therefore, please look at me,\q for surely I would not lie to your face.
\q
29:
Relent, I beg you; let there be no injustice with you;\q Indeed, relent, for my cause is just.
\q
30: Is there evil on my tongue?\q Cannot my mouth detect malicious things?
